subject: Metadata agent support in networking-ovn
commit_message:
Metadata agent support in networking-ovn

Initial implementation

Changes in the mechanism driver:

    * Automatically create a port with device_owner=network:dhcp to
      serve metadata and eventually DHCP.
    * Auto-allocate an IP for the metadata port on subnet creation.
    * Push static route for 169.254.169.254 in DHCP options.
    * Wait until metadata service is provisioned in the chassis where
      a port resides before sending the event to Nova.

Agent:

    * Implementation of [0].

Devstack plugin:

    * Starts networking-ovn-agent with the proper config files.
    * Disables config drive in nova.conf for tempest against master
      branch.
    * Enables TEMPEST_RUN_VALIDATION for tempest against master branch.

In order to test this patch out we need to make these changes to
nova.conf:

    * [DEFAULT] section:
      force_config_drive = False
    * [neutron] section:
      service_metadata_proxy = True

This patch depends on [1] and [2] (already merged into OVS master).
NOTE: Metadata tests are only enabled for the non-voting tempest job
      which runs against OVS master branch. The release job runs against
      OVS 2.7 which doesn't include [1][2] so those tests are disabled
      until OVS 2.8 is released.

[0]
https://docs.openstack.org/developer/networking-ovn/design/metadata_api.html
[1] https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/767369/
[2] https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/771297/

subject: Support pagination for resource routing list operations
commit_message:
Support pagination for resource routing list operations

1. What is the problem
The resource routing list operations will retrieve all the items in
the database, which will consume too much memory and take long time
to response when the results are considerably large.

2. What is the solution for the problem
To reduce load on the service, list operations will return a maximum
number of items at a time by pagination. To navigate the collection,
the parameters limit and marker can be set in the URI. For example:

/v1.0/routings?limit=2000&marker=500

The marker parameter is the ID of the last item in the previous list.
A marker with an invalid ID returns a badRequest (400) fault.
The limit parameter sets the page size. These parameters are optional.
If the client requests a limit beyond the maximum limit configured by
the deployment, the server returns the maximum limit number of items.
Pagination and filtering can work together with routing's list operations.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to
realize the solution
Add pagination feature for resource routing list operations.

subject: Adds value validation to the fields
commit_message:
Adds value validation to the fields

This introduce a concept of validation, which allows to check the values
of objects' fields when they are assigned.

FieldType class has got a new attribute '_validators', which is a list
of validators (functions of appropriate signature) and a 'validate'
method which iterates over the list of validators and checks
if the given value satisfies the conditions defined by those validators.

A validator is a function which accepts an object, an attribute name and
a value as paramters. It should return a tuple of a boolean and a
string, where string should contain a message to be included into
exception if the boolean is 'False'.

A Field class is mofified to call the 'validate' method of the
field_type object.

A developer may add any custom validators to any field (by passing a
list of functions / lambdas as a "validators" parameter of FieldType
constructor), but the validators for the most common field types are
included into this patch:
 - for String fields:
   - min_length - ensures the minimal length of a string
   - max_length - ensures the maximim length of a string
   - pattern - ensures that a string matches specific regex pattern

 - for Integer fields:
   - minimum - ensures that a value is greater or equal than minimum
   - maximum - ensures that a value is lower or equal than maximum
   - multiple of - ensures that a value is a multiple of specific value

 - for Float fields:
   - minimum - ensures that a value is greater or equal than minimum
   - maximum - ensures that a value is lower or equal than maximum

 - for DateTime fields:
   - minimum - ensures that a value is greater or equal than minimum
   - maximum - ensures that a value is lower or equal than maximum

To add a convinient aliases for validatable fields of appropriate type
the 'AutoTypedField' class is improved. It addition to existing
'AUTO_TYPE' attribute a new one - called 'AUTO_TYPE_CLASS' - is added.
It defines the field type not as an instance, but as a class, which gets
instantiated in field's __init__, so each field type may be
parameterized with appropriate constraints.

Appropriate field types (StringField, IntegerField, FloatField,
DateTimeField) are modified to use this new functionality.

Depends-on: Ie20377e86134a5e8b68a93a08c26ed6f3025ae9d
(The dependency is needed, as otherwise nova's unit tests will be
broken: the change of enums to coerce their 'valid_values' modifies
the string representation of unicode fields)

subject: Deprecate substituting jsonutils as a anyjson reference impl
commit_message:
Deprecate substituting jsonutils as a anyjson reference impl

Since jsonutils is used across many many different projects
and libraries it does not seem safe or smart to have that file
when it is imported to forcefully tell anyjson that this newly loaded
module is the de-facto json impl.

This is especially problematic since jsonutils loads and dumps
do specific things that are mainly openstack specific and now those
openstack specific adjustments become forced onto any 3td party or
other library that also uses anyjson...

This can lead to unexpected incompatibilities that we are forcing onto
other anyjson using modules (without there understanding of this).

To avoid this in the future *start* to move away from all these above
problems by adding a deprecation message to the function that does
this logic, letting users of jsonutils know that this functionality
will be removed in the future.

subject: Return symlinks for encrypted volumes
commit_message:
Return symlinks for encrypted volumes

When connecting encrypted volumes we need to return a symbolink link or
we will break all future attachments after detaching the volume.

OS-Brick on 1.14 and 1.15 returns real paths instead of returning symbolic
links, which results in the encryption attach_volume call replacing the
real device with a link to the crypt dm.

The issue comes from the Nova flow when attaching an encrypted volume:

1- Attach volume
2- Generate libvirt configuration with path from step 1
3- Encrypt attach volume

Since step 2 has already generated the config with the path from step 1 then
step 3 must preserve this path.

When step 1 returns a symbolic link we just forcefully replace it with a link
to the crypt dm and everything is OK, but when we return a real path it
does the same thing, which means we'll be replacing for example /dev/sda
with a symlink, which will then break the detach process, and all future
attachments.

Until Nova, Cinder, and OS-Brick are changed to have a different flow
(1, 3, 2) we need a workaround to make it work.

The workaround this patch introduces is to return a symbolic link when
the volume is encrypted.

It will try to return the symlink that always exists, but if it's not
there it will just look for ANY link to the device in '/dev/disk/by-id'.

Related-Bug: #1703954
Change-Id: If4461c3dcd67e5d948be9d9a3643c1eb81aaace9

subject: Refactor iDRAC is ready functionality
commit_message:
Refactor iDRAC is ready functionality

Web Services Management (WS-Management and WS-Man) requests/commands can
fail or return invalid results when issued to an Integrated Dell Remote
Access Controller (iDRAC) whose Lifecycle Controller remote service is
not "ready". Specifically, that applies to the WS-Man Enumerate and
Invoke operations.

A Dell technical white paper [0], "Lifecycle Controller Integration --
Best Practices Guide", states that for Lifecycle Controller firmware
1.5.0 and later "The Lifecycle Controller remote service must be in a
'ready' state before running any other WSMAN commands." That applies to
almost all of the workflows and use cases documented by that paper and
supported by this project, openstack/python-dracclient. That document
describes how to determine the readiness of the Lifecycle Controller
remote service. A project commit [1] implements that.

This refactors that patch in preparation for changing the internal
implementation of the project's APIs so that they follow that best
practice. The implementation of is_idrac_ready() and
wait_until_idrac_is_ready() have been relocated further down the call
stack, to the iDRAC specialization of the WS-Man client defined by class
dracclient.client.WSManClient. Those methods continue to be available
through the API provided by class dracclient.client.Client.

No changes have been made to this project's APIs nor to any functional
behavior.

[0]
http://en.community.dell.com/techcenter/extras/m/white_papers/20442332
[1]
https://github.com/openstack/python-dracclient/commit/39253bb272a7d4cfcc161c19708b8c6949a21240

subject: placement: claim resources in filter scheduler
commit_message:
placement: claim resources in filter scheduler

This patch adds the bulk of the code for claiming resources for
instances against a particular host during the primary _schedule() loop
in the filter scheduler. Because the state objects are tightly coupled
to the way that the filters and weighers operate in the filter
scheduler driver, we need to co-locate the claim resources code with
the code that loops through the filters and weighers.

In the code submitted here, we attempt to claim resources for each
instance in spec_obj.num_instances. For each of *those* attempts, we
keep trying to claim the resources against each host in the weighed
list of hosts returned in each loop after calling the host manager
get_filtered_hosts() method. If we fail to claim against a particular
host, we try another allocation request that matches that compute node.
If those all fail, we try the next host in the weighed hosts list.

Only if we successfully claim (in the placement API) resources for an
instance against a host do we call the host state object's
consume_from_instance() method or modify the spec_obj's instance group
state tracking. This ensures that logic around instance group affinity
and anti-affinity as well as logic that reduces resource capacity in
the host state objects only occurs if we've actually successfully
claimed resources in the placement API.

Finally, after successfully claiming resources for an instance, we
return a dict, keyed by instance UUID, that contains a list of the
allocation requests for each instance that was claimed. The first
allocation request in the list is the one that was used in the
successful claim for that instance. The remaining allocation requests
represent possible alternate destinations for the workload if the
launch request ends up failing on the originally-targeted host. All
alternate allocation requests will be for compute nodes in the same
cell as the originally-selected host.

Change-Id: Iaf3f8e688432246f0ac3b95508cc216bad771e8c

blueprint: placement-allocation-requests

subject: scheduler: alternates for filter scheduler
commit_message:
scheduler: alternates for filter scheduler

After trying to fit the square peg of allocations into the round hole
that is the current design of the scheduler, I realized that due to the
way that state is kept in the host manager and the scheduler driver,
that I would unfortunately not be able to isolate the claim logic in
the scheduler manager. Instead, due to the way that the host state
objects are passed into the filters and weighers and modified in the
filter scheduler driver's _schedule() method, it is not possible to
pull the logic for retrying a claim into a higher abstraction layer.
The coupling is just too tight between the state (host objects) and the
calling interface itself (select_destinations()).

And so this patch sets the stage for retrying claims from within the
filter scheduler's _schedule() method -- which is the method where the
state objects are being modified. We change the _schedule() method to
return a dict, keyed by instance UUID, containing lists of hosts
ordered by fitness. This dict will eventually be used to return the
list of alternate hosts for each scheduled instance, but for now, and
for the next patch which adds calls to placement to claim resources
during the filter scheduler driver's _schedule() method, we keep the
generation of alternate hosts isolated within the filter scheduler
driver only.

In cases where the deployment node is seperated from the infrastructure
node, the openstack-release file discovery logic might calculate the
wrong release since the /etc/openstack-release file does not get generated
on the deployment node.
This commit adds logic to pull down the /etc/openstack-release file from

deployment node is isolated from the infra node.

rpc-release file is made.

subject: Add possibility to filter external plugins out
commit_message:
Add possibility to filter external plugins out

For the moment, each tempest run loads all installed external
plugins, reads them and loads list of tests.
But it is redundant, tempest user may want to use only some
specific plugin or none of them for different reasons.
Since we cannot just get and disable entry points that are installed
with packages we should be able to ignore them in tempest.
So, add config group called "ext_plugin" that will contain all
options related to external plugins and define first option there
called "plugin_names_matcher". This option expects any regexp
that will be applied to tempest plugin names. By default it is
empty string that means *all* plugins will be loaded.

Examples:
1) All plugins
[ext_plugins]
plugin_names_matcher = ''

2) Only plugins that contain word 'foo'
[ext_plugins]
plugin_names_matcher = foo #foo_tests, tests_for_foo

3) Only plugins that contain word 'foo' or 'bar'
[ext_plugins]
plugin_names_matcher = foo|bar # foo_tests, bar_tests

Closes-Bug: #1604097

Current default value for the config 'blazar_az_prefix' is 'blazar:'.

According to the parse_availability_zone() [1] of the API class of Nova,
there is a legacy hack to allow admins to specify hosts via an

in the name of an availability zone itself. But Nova accepts the

from 'blazar:' to 'blazar_' which does not use ':'.
